captions.text:
TONY PADILLA: We're going to
do Buffon's needle trick.

So this is named after Georges
Louie Leclerc, and this is a

method that he proposed
for working out pi.

So basically he proposed that
you would chuck a bunch of

needles just randomly
on a floor.

You can work out pi
from that, yeah.
BRADY HARAN: Go on, then.

TONY PADILLA: Due to
the random nature.

So anyway, we haven't got
needles, and we're not going
to do it on a floor.

We're going to do it on
one of Brady's lovely
brown pieces of paper.

And we're going to use matches
instead, because we're cheap.

So what we want is we want to
draw some lines on this.
So there's one line.

And what we want is we want the
gaps between lines to be
two matches long.
This is all very approximate.

What we're going to do is we're
going to chuck a bunch
of matches on this board.

So I'll just chuck the first
two completely randomly.

We need a lot of matches
for this.

If I counted these right,
we should have 163.
Let's just spread them out.

So hopefully, there should
be 163 matches randomly
distributed around this board.

Now, this is what I've gotta do
now, is I'm going to count
how many matches cross a line.
OK, so I reckon that one does.

So you count, Brady,
that was 1, 2, 3.

13, 14, 51, and I
think that's it.

52 matches that cross
the lines.
There's 163 in total.
Now, let's see.

Let's do the following
calculation.

So 163 divided by 52
is equal to 3.13.
And that's not bad.

That's not bad, I'm quite
happy with that.

BRADY HARAN: That's
very close.
TONY PADILLA: Yeah, yeah.
So pi is 3.141.
So this is not bad.
OK, so why isn't it perfect?

Because this is not a
very large sample.

Viewers could have a little
go themselves.

Just literally play
the same game.

If you've got more matches,
that's better.
You'll get a better accuracy.

There was a mathematician
called Lazarine.

He used over 3,000 needles, and
he actually managed to get

pi accurate to I think it was
about six decimal places.

What we're seeing here is
something is akin to a Monte
Carlo simulation.
That's what it's called.

You basically take
a random sample.

The reason you get pie out of
this is it's all to do with

the angle that the match takes
as playing some role here.

And of course if you're working
in radians, if you go

through a full 360 degrees,
well, in radians that's 2 pi.

OK, so that's where pi's coming
into this game, and

that's why you can get pi
out of this sort of
setup, because the angle.

So we're going to try and
explain the maths of it now.

Let me say, imagine that the
length of the match is l, and

that means that the distance
here is 2l.

There's a few things that
play a role here.

There's the position of the
center of the match, which
I'll call there.

We'll say that's a distance
x from here.

And then the other thing that
we're interested in is the
angle the match is making.

So let's just draw it,
I guess, like so.

We're interested in
that angle beta.

Assuming everything's
completely random.

how do we measure the
probability of where the
center of the match is?

Well, the probability density
of the center of the match,

which is position x, is just
given by essentially 1/l.

The other thing that we're
interested in is
the angle it makes.

So this is sort of a measure
of the probability of the
angle it's making.

And basically, the angles that
we're interested in are

somewhere between 0 and pi/2
which is of course 90 degrees.

This is where the
pi's coming in.

Now, if we want to work out
essentially the probability

for the match to cross the
line, what we do is
we take these two.
We have to do an integration.

OK, now there's an important
point here.

What's the condition for the
match to cross the line?

Well, the condition for the
match to cross the line is

that x should be less
than l/2 sine theta.

So that means when we do the x
integration, we go between 0
and l/2 sine theta.

OK, and of course when we do the
theta integration, we're
going between 0 and pi by 2.

So we do it, theta equals 0,
this is pi/2, 2 over l pi.
2 over l pi.

When we do the x integration, we
get an l over 2 sine theta.

And then we integrate sine theta
between 0 and pi by 2.

That gives me 1, and I've
got the 1/pi there, so
the answer is 1/pi.

This tells me the probability
that you're going to cross the
line, right?

So if I've got n matches, and
I want to work out how many

cross, let me call them--
so this is the n total.

And I want to work out
how many cross.

Then I just multiply
and total that.
1/pi.
So n total is 163.

And n crossing was 52, I think
we got, didn't we?
OK.

So what you see from that
if we've got 163/pi.

Let's put an approximate
sign in there.

Approximately 52, or if you
like, what we actually saw was

that pi, just rearrange
this equation, so
approximately 163/52.
Yeah, I'm happy with that.
Yeah, yeah.
That's good.
So that's how it works.
That's the theory behind it.

comments.author: Cole Wheatley

comments.text:
why overcomplicate?
if match length is 1, then its average "reach" is the average value of sinx 
from 0 to π/2, which is equal to
[ ∫[from 0 to π/2] (sinxdx) ] / (π/2)
= 2/π

And the probability is the average reach divided by the distance between 
two lines and you get 1/π. One simple integral﻿

comments.author: Terry Moore

comments.text:
Buffon himself got more accurate estimates than he should have when taking 
account of random variation. He didn't use a fixed sample size, but stopped 
when he had 6 correct digits.
There is a much more beautiful proof that doesn't use calculus. It's based 
on the number of crossings (which is 0 or 1 if the needle is shorter than 
the line spacing).
Using the fact that the mean of a sum is the sum of the means, the average 
number of crossings doesn't depend on the shape of the needle--it could 
even be a shoelace. And the average number is proportional to the length of 
the needle. To see this imagine the needle chopped into a large number of 
tiny pieces. The whole is the sum of the parts. Next suppose the needle is 
bent into a circle which just fits between the lines. If d is the line 
spacing the length of the needle is d x pi. There will (almost) always be 
two crossings, so the average number is 2. Therefore the average number per 
unit length is 2/(d pi) giving (2 l)/(d pi) for a needle of length l.﻿
comments.author: Terry Moore

comments.author: KomhKs

comments.text:
I'm sorry but I'm calling bs on him picking up EXACTLY 52 matches. had he 
picked up 51; 163/51=~3.196 and had he picked up 53; 163/53=~3.075. What 
are the odds of him picking up the exact number that would give him the 
closest possible approximation to pi? Im not arguing with the fact that 
this method gives you pi, but im saying that the distribution of the number 
of matchsticks he would pick up has a mean of 52 but it also has a standard 
deviation that would  mean the vast majority of the time you wont pick up 
52﻿
comments.author: rgqwerty63

comments.text:
+rgqwerty63 
Whether he cheated or not the question you should be asking yourself is not 
how he picked up fifty two matches but why he did not multiply the 
numerator by 2 or divide by the length of the spacing * the numbers of 
needles that cross the line but we still have the value pi.


 In most text book I have read the formula says that the total needles must 
be multiplied by 2 then divided by the number of needles that touch the 
line * the spacing.

My maths calculations
===========

 Buffon's needle problem can be performed empirically by first drawing 
parallel lines one unit of length apart on a plane surface and then 
randomly dropping needles of unit length on the surface. Multiply the 
length 'l' of matchstick by 2 and use this number as the numerator of a a 
ratio. Count the probability of the number of needles that cross the line 
times the spacing of the line d. Use this count for the dominator.

l = assume that the average matchstick length is 40 mm
d = spacing of the grid was 2 matchstick therefore spacing 2*40 = 80mm
p = 52/163 = 0.3190184049079

pi = 2*l /p*d
pi = 2*40/0.3190184049079*80 = 3.13461538

What is really interesting is he did not use the value 2 nor did he 
multiply it by the line spacing but yet the answer is relatively the same.
comments.author: MathsForever

comments.text:
+Alexander Reynolds Which is higher: the chance of him randomly getting 52 
or the chance of him doing it on purpose?
The answer to that question depends on the chances of getting 52 vs getting 
NOT 52.
comments.author: Joseph Gitarts

comments.text:
You don't have to explain the same thing 100 times. Yes, I know the chances 
of getting specifically a 52 compared to not getting a 52 are small. But 
you have to compare like with like. As I mentioned before, getting a 51, or 
a 50, compared to not 51 or not 50 is a very small chance as well. In fact 
getting ANY specific number is a small chance. You cannot compare the 
micro-phenomenon with the entire system like that for a useful analysis.

For an example on how this fails, consider a roulette table. Even if it 
hits four black numbers in a row, this tells you NOTHING about the 
likeliness of the next number being red.
comments.author: Alexander Reynolds

comments.text:
+Alexander Reynolds Look, we know that 52 is special. The chances of 
getting 52 are very small. If you then pick up the nails and count them 
getting 52 is ridiculously unlikely but getting anything else other than 52 
is expected.

Its like someone with a deck of cards who shuffles randomly, then says he's 
gonna pull out the 6 of hearts. It is expected that he would pull something 
that isn't the 6 hearts. ie it wont be surprising pulling out a 10 or queen 
of some suit. It would be surprising if he pulled out the 6 hearts because 
we have already given it special status. Same as picking up 52 nails
comments.author: rgqwerty63

comments.text:
+Alexander Reynolds Ok look:
Let's say you are playing a game with an opponent who has to through a 
1000-sided uneven dice, such that the chance of rolling 500 is the highest, 
say, 1/200. The chance of not rolling 500 is therefore 199/200, however for 
each individual number the chance is smaller than 1/200. If he rolls 500 he 
wins, otherwise you win.
You know that he has a chance to cheat without you noticing. He rolls the 
dice and gets 500. Would you not suspect him?
comments.author: Joseph Gitarts

comments.text:
+Joseph Gitarts It doesn't make sense to compare 52 vs not 52. If he picked 
51 it wouldn't be highly unlikely to pick 51 out of not 51. But for some 
reason that wouldn't raise questions for you. If someone got 999 on a 1000 
sided die roll yes perhaps it'd be surprising but it has an equal 
likelihood of being picked as 597. It's not suspect because it is equally 
likely. In this case it's actually the MOST likely compared to the other 
options. I understand your argument, but you cannot compare them like that. 
With that view the fact that everything in the world happens is just 
surprising because the chance that it would happen is virtually 
non-existent. But, everything happens.
comments.author: Alexander Reynolds

comments.text:
+Alexander Reynolds We are arguing whether he did it on purpose or not. If 
he'd picked any number other than 52, it is clearly random. But exactly 52 
raises questions, because this is the one number which you would want to 
pick.
Think of this: There are numbers from 1 to 1,000,000 and you pick randomly, 
however the chance to pick 999,999 is 1/10,000 instead 1/1,000,000. The 
chance of picking 999,999 is higher than that of any other number; however 
you will not be surprised if you pick, say, 512,806 because it is just some 
number out of the blue and doesn't mean anything but you will be surprised 
if you pick 999,999 because it does.
In this case we are comparing not the chances of individual numbers, but 
the chance of picking 52 vs NOT picking 52.
comments.author: Joseph Gitarts

comments.text:
+Joseph Gitarts I understand. But it is even less likely he'd choose 51 
instead of 52. There's a smaller chance of picking 50, or 49. Is it 
surprising that he'd pick SOME number in the distribution? No...Well, you 
could make the same argument. There's a huge chance he wouldn't pick 51, 
compared to all non 51 numbers. Wouldn't be surprising if he picked it.
comments.author: Alexander Reynolds

comments.text:
+Alexander Reynolds  But its still not the majority, and in fact even 
thought the chance of picking 52 is greater than that of any other number, 
it is still very low. And here we're arguing 52 vs NOT 52.
comments.author: Joseph Gitarts

comments.text:
What? If the center of the distribution IS on 52 then it's quite highly 
likely that you'll end up there; of course there is a standard deviation 
that you can expect to be in but it literally means if you repeat this 
experiment thousands of times, more often than any other number of 
matchsticks, you'll pick 52. It's totally reasonable.

comments.text:
I replayed the video and he says density of probability Px is 1/l. So to 
find out the probabiliy for  x to be in a certain interval, let say x1 and 
x2 you have to integrate Px over this interval [x1,x2]. The reason it is 
1/l is because you need your integral over the whole space to be 1, but 
your match stops at x = l, so you integrate Px from 0 to l which is Px * l 
and this must be 1.
Px * l = 1 <=> Px = 1/l

Hope it's more or less helping...

comments.text:
+Scott Gauer Lol you cant do a taylor series approximation of a constant. 
Taylor series approximations are used to obtain power series approximations 
of functions such as sin(x), cos(x), e^x, or any other function. You can 
get good approximations for pi and e by plugging certain numbers into 
taylor approximations, but you cant "do the taylor series approximation for 
pi".

comments.author: koolguy728

comments.text:
+ThatRubikGuy Just because something is the most frequent answer doesn't 
mean it is frequent. The answer of 27:1 is incorrect though. You can find 
the probability that of it being exactly 52 out of 163 like this (assuming 
the probability of each is 1/pi) :
(1/pi)^52 * (1 - 1/pi)^111 * (163! / (52! * 111!)) = 0.067 or about 1/15
comments.author: HowToCantaloupe

comments.text:
It is just like spinning an coin, there 50/50 change to get heads or tails 
but it doesn't mean if you spin it only 10 times, you'll get 5 heads. but 
if you did it like a million times, probability will take over and you 
should get something very close to 50/50

So to put it simple, the more nails you use, the more precise the pi value 
will be.

but if you repeated this experiment a million times, the most frequent 
result would be 52.

comments.text: Can you explain how the probability of angle placement is 2/pi?﻿
comments.author: Beejay Cruz

comments.text:
You consider that any angle between 0 (horizontal match) and pi/2 (vertical 
match) is equally likely for a particular match.
Any match will have 1 particular angle out of pi/2 possible options. 
Therefore, the probability will be 1/(pi/2), which simplifies to 2/pi.

+dt It would, but that's not ideal. If the board were cylindrical (the 
right edge connects directly to the left edge), and there were a purposely 
bare area, that would skew the results away from Pi. I believe the proof is 
that as it stands, the result consistently tends towards pi.

It will always be approximate to pi but never ever exactly pi because pi is 
irrational, meaning it cannot be expressed as a fraction. If you ever do 
this and end up with the exact value of pi (which is impossible) you found 
a fraction that expresses pi ﻿

true, but if u had an infinite amount of matches, then u would find that if

closer and closer to the value of pi each day

comments.text:
If you were to use degrees instead of radians you would get a different 
answer. So does this mean that the universe uses radians?﻿
comments.author: ‫עמרי טפלא‬‎

comments.text:
+Romy Williamson You would get the same answer. The probabilities of events 
in the real world don't care which unit you use
comments.author: dt

comments.text:
Well, it means that degrees are just a convention and radians are a much 
more fundamental unit.
comments.author: Romy Williamson

comments.text:
Essentially yes. The idea of there being 360 degrees in a full circle is 
completely arbitrary. 360 was chosen because it is easily divisible. In 
radians, a full circle is 2*Pi and Pi is a mathematical constant that we 
observe in nature.
comments.author: Simon May

comments.text:
if you use degrees instead of radians in this process, you actually have a 
unit attached to the end result. you cannot have the unit attached since 
you are attempting to find pi. You are forced to use radians since radians 
are called "pure numbers", they do not have a unit attched and thus allows 
pi to be calculated this way.
comments.author: Saad Mehr

comments.text:
You can't integrate a trig function in degrees, which is why radians exist 
in the first place
comments.author: Banana Hunter Pro

comments.text:
I don't really know much about the universe's preferences, but I can tell 
you that in this particular case this thing works merely because pi is (by 
definition) the result you get when you divide half the circumference of a 
circle by its radius. Had it been equal to , say 4, instead of 3.1415... 
then the integral would have yield 1/4.
comments.author: giovanni9107

comments.text:
Simply put, yes.  The universe uses radians.  Degrees are a human construct 
that don't have any basis in the physical world anymore than us using a 
base 10 counting system is because we have 10 fingers.  Degrees could have 
just as easily have been based on 180, or 256 or 5 or 10,000 or 7.457896 
any other number other than 360.
comments.author: Kevin Bland

comments.text: No, it means you don't know math.
comments.author: EmaStorm

comments.text:
PI is a fundemental constant of the universe.  If you are hung up about the 
name 'pi', then you are missing the point.
comments.author: AdamWho

comments.text:
Radians are measured in pi. That has nothing to do with the universe. 
Humans made up the system of measuring radians. Degrees are another system 
made up by humans that does not use pi.
comments.author: beauxq

comments.text: what religious beliefs?
comments.author: ‫עמרי טפלא‬‎

comments.text:
Yes, the universe does use radians.  Degrees are completely arbitrary and 
an artifact of ancient religious beliefs.
comments.author: AdamWho

comments.text:
No, it just means that you would get appx. 180 which is not nearly as

comments.author: Kasper Emanuel Stæger

comments.text:
yes, degrees are just a random angular measure for the commoners. Also,

comments.author: ‫עמרי טפלא‬‎

comments.text:
No, if you do a definite integral of the sin function in degrees, then you 
get a different antiderivative while also changing the limits of the 
integral. The answer doesn't change. We use radians because it makes the 
calculations a lot easier.
comments.author: stevibxyz

comments.text:
Basically, radians already have the necessary information built into them 
to solve the problem. If you started with degrees, you would just have to 
do one more step (which is the same step to convert degrees to radians). 
That step involves using the definition of pi where one turn around the 
circle (or 360 degrees) is 2*pi*radius.
comments.author: KrunchyGoodness

comments.text:
No, you could do all of these calculations out in terms of degrees but you 
would find it to be a roundabout way of doing things.  The trig functions 
inside the integrals will process degrees and put out the same answer.

What the hell are you talking about? Also the equation tells us mass and

speed at which massless particles must travel squared. "Light will 
continuously radiate out in every direction at a constant speed" no, it 
won't, photons travel in straight lines, and can be absorbed or slowed down

comments.text:
Wouldn't you get more accurate results when the distance between the lines 
would equal the length of the needle? Of course you would need to do 
2*(ntotal)/(ncross), but look at these 95% confidence intervals for 163 
matches: - Using d=2l: [(1/pi + 1.96sqrt((1/pi)*(1-1/pi)/163))^-1; (1/pi - 
1.96sqrt((1/pi)*(1-1/pi)/163))^-1] = [2.56527; 4.0519] - Using d=l: 
[2*(2/pi + 1.96*sqrt((2/pi)*(1-2/pi)/200))^-1; 2*((2/pi - 
1.96*sqrt((2/pi)*(1-2/pi)/200))^-1] = [2.81508, 3.55378]

comments.text:
No. With the same reasoning: if you get a heads 100 times in a row from 
throwing heads/tails, would that mean that the probability to get heads is 
1? No, it means that you have been "lucky", and should do more throws to 
get a more accurate example.
comments.author: ChokiiRS

comments.text:
I'd say you spreading out the matches as evenly as possible will result in 
essentially dependent samples from the "uniform" distribution you are 
trying to sample resulting in an artificially "good" result. You should not 
be getting such a good results with such a small number of samples, so you 
should warn the watchers of these subtleties, especially as these things 
can give you wrong results in more complicated situations (for example - 
measure the avg smallest distance between matches.)
comments.author: maxp3141

comments.text:
You could get it exactly right with an infinite number of matches tossed 
into an infinite space, but otherwise you will only ever get an 
approximation with accuracy based on how many matches you had and how 
accurately you could count them.
